1584235878_19K65385dRL6Z5EPFVEmxpbgJh8CU.body: I like Thomas Sowell's explanation. A right is something conveyed between two parties. Both benefit from it yet it costs them nothing.

That was my paraphrase and not a quote.  "Both benefit and neither is diminished" might be better. 
As I remember, Sowell was discussing health care. He argued that it could not be a right because some benefit  while others pay.
Take the oft quoted "The pen is mightier than the sword." On its face, that's ridiculous. The entire quote is "In civilized societies, the pen is mightier than the sword." Civilized people don't hack up those with whom they disagree. It's unacceptable and it's certainly not a right. You have no right to beat someone up because that right was never given you.
For the most part, I agree with your last sentence. An attorney acquaintance once quipped, "There is no such thing as justice. There is only law."

> [thefather](#comment_3_1QF6hFgijw5BqUeyY9hRPmH7qxcaRvgCyM): I still support and agree with vaccination. 
Unfortunately, we're not dealing with vaccines here. You are not being inoculated with an inactivated virus which would allow your body to create a normal immune response. Instead, your cells get a recipe to create only one particular component of the virus, the spike protein. This applies to both the mRNA and virus vector shots. How long will your cells continue to churn out spike proteins? Who knows? Will it result in Antibody Enhanced Disease? For some people, it looks like it already has. Again, we're not being offered a vaccine here. We're being coerced to participate in a mammoth medical experiment.
